displayed_text: Patient: …W____ I’ll - I can be on a plane. I can drive it… Doctor: Okay. Okay. Patient: …in nine hours, in - I can drive it in thirteen hours it’s not a big deal. Doctor: Let’s work on that scheduling so I just want to recap so we’re straight… Patient: Yep. Doctor: …and then you tell me if this, actually you tell me, you tell me what I just said so that we’re straight. What’s our plan? Patient: Our plan is we’re gonna, we’re gonna probably we’re gonna go and we’re gonna go to radiation onc - uh radiation I’m gonna say oncology. Doctor: Radiology. Patient: Radiology well, okay. Doctor: Yeah. Yeah. Patient: And we’re gonna go and we’re gonna go find that uh that two centimeter uh mass. Doctor: Okay.

Patient: Um hum. Doctor: You know, if down the road if there are kidney problems. At least what they’ve reported so far they don’t - they don’t see it. Patient: I see. Doctor: So I would say the procedure, I normally do it on the trials, but I had this experience with the guys in Germany. What they do is they bring you there and they scan you. Patient: Okay. Doctor: With the imaging part. They see how active is your cancer. How much of the stuff is there on PSMA. Patient: Okay. Doctor: If there’s a lot there, so things look really dark, it looks like it’s taken up like crazy, then you’re a good candidate for that treatment. If it’s so-so, I don’t know what their line is, but they kind of look at it, and if it doesn’t look like the cancer is really taken off, I don’t think you’re a candidate. I would say that most people are in the first group that the cancer makes a lot of this uh so uh one of the things we’re doing here is uh looking at the scan part. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So we’ve been looking at the imaging part to see how useful this is as an imaging agent but it’s also useful because if we do it here, and you’re very positive, it might suggest yes we should pursue this. Patient: Okay. Is it something than can tell you how extensive the cancer? Doctor: Yes. So the second part of that, it’s a good question. Just to, and because it’s very sensitive, it’s possible you do the scan, and they, say, oh, B__, your set of these, so many things you see here, there’s a lot more. Because they can see uh, what we’re limited by right now is as I told you these lymph nodes are enlarged. That’s pretty much all the radiologist can say right now. So if you have a normal lymph node it could be totally full of cancer. They won’t call it. They only call the ones that are bigger than normal.

Patient: Yes. Doctor: It sounds like we’re going to keep you on the study for now. In order to do so, we have to stop the medication to allow this anemia to recover. Hopefully, it will. Uh, so as of today, uh, no more Patient: Okay. Doctor: Until you come back and see us on September the fifth. Uh, L___ will be in touch with you after she comes back. Family Member: She’ll be here tomorrow. Doctor: She actually had to leave unexpectedly because her house had some flooding which she had to take care of, which is why she’s not here. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: But, uh, we will schedule the, uh, complete blood count which includes hemoglobin for next Monday, Tuesday, or Wednesday, the early part of next week. Based on that, I will make a decision about whether a transfusion will be necessary or not. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: If the transfusion is necessary, we’ll also do that through the K___ system. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And we will have all that completed before September fifth. So that when you come back, we’ll give you the best possible chance to start the medication again, albeit at a lower dose, because it’ll be the two-hundred milligram dose.

Patient: I mean yeah living, dining area, a little kitchenette. You go down the hall with two bedrooms and a bathroom at the end. It’s nicer than, it’s bigger than my one at home, at home. Doctor: Oh, my, gosh. Patient: I don’t know if I still have it- Doctor: Wait a minute. So is this? Patient: B___’s house. Yeah. Doctor: This is B___’s house? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Do you see him or is he on tour? Patient: I saw, no, you know, he’s having some uh medical problems Doctor: Oh, no. Patient: Are we in the cone of silence here? Doctor: Well, you’re on. Hey. Could you guys, can you guys put down the thingy? The, the cut this part out? Patient: Uh, I can tell you, I can tell you when we’re walking out.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.None: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::None

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.agree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::agree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.agree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::agree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.disagree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::disagree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.disagree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::disagree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.disagree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::disagree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.neutral: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::neutral

People of my ethnic group are treated th.neutral: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::neutral

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.agree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::agree

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.College graduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::College graduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.White: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::White

displayed_text: Healthcare Professional: No. What they’re trying to do is figure out whether it does work better than… Family Member: Yeah. Yeah. Healthcare Professional: Than that or the um Xtandi plus the other pill. So that’s what the study is. Xtandi is already approved for… Doctor: I want to be part of this discussion too. Doctor: Of course I am. I’m the one directing it. Patient: How are you doing? Doctor: I’m alright. How are you Mr. H___? Nice to see you. How are you? Family Member: Good to see you again. Doctor: Yes, definitely. No you’re good. Healthcare Professional: I was just explaining… Family Member: There’s a chair over there. Healthcare Professional: I’m sorry?

Patient: Well, I mean- Doctor: Yeah. Patient: -at least we’re going to get them all. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: But I mean - I don’t know. Doctor: Yeah, you just need to know where he wants to put the Patient: I can give you his contact information. Doctor: Yeah, I mean he’s at B___, right? Is it at B___ – L__ at B___? Patient: I think he’s at B___ or some other. Yeah, I’m not getting the radiation. Doctor: Is he T____? Patient: No, I might have some contact information. Doctor: Uh, okay it’s like K_ (spells name)

Family Member: I don't know where she got it from. Doctor: Let me tell you because it was good. Family Member: It smells good. Doctor: Did you want one? Family Member: No. Doctor: There's more. Family Member: No, no, no, we're going to get pizza. Doctor: Why is your PSA 10?! Patient: I don’t know! Doctor: Let me whine some more. What the hell? Are you taking your pills? Patient: Mhmm. Religiously. Doctor: Are you taking four or are you taking three? Patient: Four.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: You kind of pretty much know if you are on the vitamin C though. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Because you do get flushing and you know kind of like what you think about high-dose vitamins. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh, so I think it’s worth a go at least to think about it. Patient: I should, now will I be, if I, like if I go to the hotel and get a ride over. Doctor: Um hum. Patient: And I went back to the hotel. Doctor: Um hum. Patient: Would I be okay to like to go back there by myself? Doctor: Oh, yeah.

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: So that way if any questions… Family Member: You’ll come back today you mean? Doctor: Yeah. I do. Yeah, yeah. Family Member: I didn’t know if we have to come back. Doctor: I figured if he explained to you first and then if any questions come up and all that, I will come back. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: That’s why I’m saying that that’s um you know I’ll do that twice just so… Family Member: Okay. Patient: You know I got an appointment with you later in June does that cancel? Doctor: No we’ll cancel that because we don’t need it. Yeah don’t worry about that. (Laughs) Patient: Well I was just wondering. Doctor: Yeah we’ll figure that out.

Patient: Um did you have to do radiation on them? Doctor: In some of those patients yes. Patient: Um hmm. Doctor: Right and uh um. Patient: Did you come high? Doctor: Not high immediately, but uh… Patient: Um hmm. Doctor: …it continues to rise. Patient: Um hmm. Doctor: And in those patients we may offer radiation therapy, radiation therapy with hormonal therapy. Patient: Um hmm. Doctor: But we’ll wait and see what happens in your case.

Patient: Sure. Doctor: …of the pelvis and targeting ah systems that they have is very accurate. As accurate as we can get with the current state-of-the-art, but… Patient: What would they be targeting? Doctor: They would be targeting the bed where the prostate was removed. Patient: Oh just around – around the urethra and th - Doctor: Correct, correct. Patient: - seminal vesicles and (patient talking over doctor) Doctor: So when we talk about side effects there’s always the potential – Patient: Right. Doctor: - for you know unintended injury to things in that area like the bladder, the urethra, ah the colon which - or the rectum which sits right behind. Patient: Sure. Doctor: You can have things like blood in the urine. You can have problems with healing in that area. That’s why we don’t automatically refer people immediately…

Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: And kind of try to, and then I’m going to find out probably today or tomorrow what this color test --- Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: I don’t get anything from this test. It’s just an easy one to do. Family Member: Yeah, you know what MTHFR is? Do you know is that related to this? Because our daughter has that. Doctor: I don’t know what that means. Family Member: She also has an autoimmune disease. Doctor: What is MTHFR? Family Member: That’s some genetic thing, right? Patient: Yeah. Family Member: Our youngest daughter. Patient: That was discovered and looked at by a guy named A_

Family Member: But the study itself is for two years. Doctor: Yes, yes. Yes, yes. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: All right. So let me, um yeah, so this is the so this is the part that's part of the research that's going to be free of charge. So right now what we'll do is the blood for this is the specific gene that we're looking for. And then if you join the study, and you have the right genotype, we'll get all of these and then these other things are not part of their like part of standard treatment. So those don't get paid for by the study they get paid for by your insurance company as normal. Patient: By insurance. Doctor: So if you are okay with this, I will get your signature there and then. You have to put the time. Time is 450 Family Member: So he’ll go downstairs and get his blood drawn. Doctor: Yes. All right. So let me make a copy of this though for you for your records. Family Member: We’re very thankful for meeting you. And how thorough you are. And how comfortable, you make you know, it makes me feel comfortable. Doctor: Thank you. Thank you. I always tell me I'm not happy that we met under the circumstances- Patient: Yes. Doctor: - but try make the best of it.

Patient: Um hum. Doctor: it was like oh, no you kind of had these bits and pieces, Patient: Right. Doctor: one, your insurance won’t approve it and number two it’s the wrong treatment. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But, if that’s sort of gone and nowhere to be found on this CAT scan then I think radium is it. Now, radium does two things. One is that it helps you live longer but also helps with pain so those people who are, you know, whether you’re taking a Tylenol over-the-counter or you’re taking actual narcotics that should improve. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So, you know, all the new studies are like hey, radium and phone a friend, you know, radium and Xtandi, radium and chemo, radium and whatever. So, they’re all in studies but not standard of care yet. I’m gonna pause right there and see how you guys are doing. This is not a test. There’s no test. No test. Family Member: Okay, he was asking when we were waiting for you. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: If the treatment you’re going to give him is going to make him feel better Patient: Yes. Family Member: or is he still gonna feel fatigued and miserable.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: Yeah and so we’ll be looking to do that anyway. But I agree with you. We should make that decision you know before then. Patient: We will. I will talk to my wife. As a matter of fact when we leave here I’m going to head to the rehab. Doctor: Okay. Patient: And the four of us can kind of you know talk. But I think that’s the direction that we’ll probably go- Doctor: Once you have a clearer picture of you know which way you want to go, whether it’s radiotherapy with hormones for now or hormones plus or minus some secondary therapy which may work better, then I would also like to talk to you about some of the clinical trials in each of those categories. Since they are mutually exclusive right now. It’s kind of either like a radiotherapy based trial or hormone therapy plus something new. So once - Family Member: I’m sorry; say that one more time. You say it’s two? What are the two again? Doctor: The -the two general like avenues that we could go; one is radiotherapy to target that lymph node. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: And we have a trial to do that through H__. And the other one is to skip the radiotherapy and go directly to hormone therapy. And then we have a trial looking to see whether combining something with hormone therapy is better than hormone therapy alone. Patient: Uh hum. Family Member: Well what is the something?
